title: Matrix Product States (MPS)
content:
Matrix Product States #  Origins: DMRG #  The Density Matrix Renormalization Group algorithm is a numerical method developed by Stephen White
Infinite DMRG #   Step 1: Superblock Hamiltonian #    \[H = - J \sum_{j=1}^N \sigma_j \sigma_{j+1} - h \sum_{j=1}^N \sigma_j\]    Step 2: Select target state #   \[H_{BB} = Q \Lambda Q^\dagger\]  Usually, the desired state is the ground state which corresponds to eigenstate with the lowest eigenvalue.  \[\Psi = Q(\min \lambda)\]   \[H_{BB} | \Psi \rangle = \lambda_0 |\Psi\rangle \quad \lambda_0 = \min(\lambda)\]  We could update  \(H_B\)  to be the outer product of the
 \[\tilde\Psi_{ij} = \sum_\alpha \Psi_{ij\alpha\alpha}\]   \[[H_B]_{ij;i^\prime j^\prime} = | \tilde\Psi_{ij} \rangle \langle \tilde\Psi_{i^\prime j^\prime} |\]  Step 3: Low-rank representation of the reduced density matrix #  Instead, the DMRG uses the reduced density matrix to find a better representation of  \(H_B\)  . The reduced density matrix is a much more appropiate tool to deal with the representation of subsystems and mixed quantum states.
 \[\rho_{i j;i^\prime j^\prime} = \sum_{k,w} |\Psi_{i,j,k,w}\rangle \langle \Psi_{i^\prime,j^\prime,k,w} |\]  We want to find the minimal ensemble of states that better approximates the reduced density matrix  \(\rho\)  .
 \[\rho = U \Lambda U^\dagger\]  Let  \(\lambda_1, \dots, \lambda_m\)  be the  \(m\)  highest eigenvalues of  \(\rho\)  , then the new  \(H_B\)  is the matrix formed by the associated eigenvectors.
 \[[H_B]_{ij;\alpha} = U_{ij;\alpha} \qquad 1 \leq \alpha \leq m\]   \[\rho \approx H_B \tilde\Lambda H_B^\dagger\]  Finite DMRG #
